query: My care needs assessment in southampton says I need 20 hours of home care weekly, but I'm worried about costs. What financial help is available?

Paying For Residential Care - Factsheet

Paying for residential care - information from Southampton City Council about how you will need to contribute towards the cost of your residential care

If you decide that staying in your own home is no longer right for you then you and your care manager can talk about the kind of residential or nursing home you need. Moving into residential care is a big decision and can have major financial implications.

If you have over £23,250 in savings you will be required to pay for the full costs of your care. If you have less than this amount in savings you may be entitled to financial help if it is agreed by you and social services that this is the best kind of care for you.

If you wish to move into residential care and you have sufficient income and resources to pay for this yourself, you may arrange this independently. However, if most of your assets are tied up in your home, you may still wish to approach the council for help.

. We have created a care self-assessment tool which can help you understand if you are eligible to receive help. It can also put you in touch with the right organisations to help and support you. Try our care self-assessment tool . View more information about needs and eligibility . Personal Budgets and Direct Payments SHOW The Care Act states that, since April 2015, councils will need to allocate a personal budget to all people who are eligible for support. The personal budget is the amount of money needed to cover the cost of a person’s eligible support. View more information about personal budgets . Anyone who is eligible will also be offered a direct payment. Many people in Southampton already receive direct payments. This means individuals have total control of how they receive the best care and support for them. Find out more about direct payments . Care planning and reviews SHOW A person’s care plan will be reviewed on a regular basis, and if or when their needs change

contacting Adult Social Care (see our Contacts Page ). 
• The Care Quality Commission (CQC) carry out annual inspections on all care homes. You can 
view their most recent inspection reports on the CQC website , or contact them on 0300 061 
6161 to obtain a paper copy of a report.  The CQC also regulate many non -residential care 
providers.

The only people who do not contribute to the cost of their care at all are those who have ‘continuing NHS health care’ which is care arranged and paid for by the NHS. (This is different to ‘free nursing care’ which is the payment from the health service for the nursing element of a person’s care after they have been assessed by a registered nurse).

Only people who normally live in Southampton can apply for financial help from Southampton City Council. Anyone who lives in another part of the country and needs financial help with the fees for a Southampton home should start by contacting their own local authority.

Short stays

These are temporary stays to give you or your carer a break, or for emergency situations (for example, if your carer has to go into hospital).

answer:
If you are assessed as needing 20 hours of home care weekly in Southampton, you may be eligible for financial help depending on your financial circumstances. **If your savings are below £23,250**, you might qualify for assistance from the council.

- **Personal Budgets and Direct Payments**: If you are eligible for support, you will be allocated a personal budget to cover the cost of your care. You can also opt for direct payments, which give you control over how you manage your care services. More information about personal budgets and direct payments can be found on the Southampton City Council website.

- **Financial Assessment**: The council will conduct a financial assessment to determine how much you need to contribute towards your care costs. Depending on the outcome, you may need to pay some or all of the costs.

- **NHS Continuing Healthcare**: In some cases, if your care needs are primarily health-related, you might be eligible for NHS Continuing Healthcare, which covers the full cost of care.

For more detailed information and to explore your options, you should contact Southampton City Council's Adult Social Care services. You can also use their care self-assessment tool to understand your eligibility for financial help. Visit their website at [Southampton City Council Adult Social Care](https://www.southampton.gov.uk/adult-social-care) for further guidance and support.
